qas.question: What term was coined to differentiate better sounding products in the 1920s?
What magazines provided reviews for audio equipment?
What happened in 1958 that changed the home music scene?

answers.text: variety of improvements in recording and playback technologies

qas.question: During what years did the term HiFi take off with engineers?
What term would be used when one said they produced perfect sound reproduction?

context: The term "<a0_0><a4_0>high fidelity<a4_0/><a0_0/>" was coined in the 1920s by some manufacturers of radio receivers and phonographs to differentiate their better-sounding products claimed as providing "perfect" sound reproduction. The term began to be used by some audio engineers and consumers through the <a3_0>1930s and 1940s<a3_0/>. After 1949 a <a2_0>variety of improvements in recording and playback technologies<a2_0/>, especially stereo recordings, which became widely available in 1958, gave a boost to the "hi-fi" classification of products, leading to sales of individual components for the home such as amplifiers, loudspeakers, phonographs, and tape players. <a1_0>High Fidelity and Audio<a1_0/> were two magazines that hi-fi consumers and engineers could read for reviews of playback equipment and recordings.
